flags.title: User-Contributed Project
flags.text: This project guide is not managed by MAKE staff.

guide.introduction: This year we are going with a spider-themed house and we will have a "Hedge of Heads" that showcases spiderweb-wrapped heads, etc. (doll parts) trapped in webbing on the hedges or bushes (creepy both day & night). This simple guide will show how we create creepy web-wrapped heads.
guide.introduction_rendered:
This year we are going with a spider-themed house and we will have a "Hedge of Heads" that showcases spiderweb-wrapped heads, etc. (doll parts) trapped in webbing on the hedges or bushes (creepy both day & night). This simple guide will show how we create creepy web-wrapped heads.

Relevant parts
  • doll parts
  • Polypropylene Webbing
Tools
  • Paper cutter, scissors, or utility knife

lines.text: Here are a few completed heads (not yet installed into hedge) wrapped up and ready to go.
lines.text_raw: Here are a few completed heads (not yet installed into hedge) wrapped up and ready to go.

lines.text: The excess webbing you see will be spread out on the bush or hedge once installed.
lines.text_raw: The excess webbing you see will be spread out on the bush or hedge once installed.

lines.text: Doll parts!! The more the merrier! Here is a pile of whole heads and half-shells of doll faces .... doll arms ... doll legs .... you get the idea. Some have been scorched from a previous year's zombie theme or ???
lines.text_raw: Doll parts!! The more the merrier! Here is a pile of whole heads and half-shells of doll faces .... doll arms ... doll legs .... you get the idea. Some have been scorched from a previous year's zombie theme or ???

lines.text: You will also need some webbing they sell for spiderweb decor at the party stores, etc. It comes in a sort of sheet of threads that you can spread apart into webbing. I tear off small bits for the wraps.
lines.text_raw: You will also need some webbing they sell for spiderweb decor at the party stores, etc. It comes in a sort of sheet of threads that you can spread apart into webbing. I tear off small bits for the wraps.

lines.text: Tear a small (1/2 inch or so) strand off the webbing mass. Yank or pull on this to "fluff" it up, then spread it out on a smooth surface.
lines.text_raw: Tear a small (1/2 inch or so) strand off the webbing mass. Yank or pull on this to "fluff" it up, then spread it out on a smooth surface.

lines.text: Fold layer over once to create a thicker rectangle of webbing.
lines.text_raw: Fold layer over once to create a thicker rectangle of webbing.

lines.text: Place doll head in center of web.
lines.text_raw: Place doll head in center of web.

lines.text: Cup the head and pull the webbing up around the head, like wrapping a gift basket from bottom to top. Stretch out the strands to fully envelop the head.
lines.text_raw: Cup the head and pull the webbing up around the head, like wrapping a gift basket from bottom to top. Stretch out the strands to fully envelop the head.

lines.text: You should end up with a "ponytail" of webbing on top of the doll head, ready to tie off.
lines.text_raw: You should end up with a "ponytail" of webbing on top of the doll head, ready to tie off.

steps.title: Tie Me Up, Tie Me Down!

lines.text: Once you have the wrapping up around the head you need to tie it securely with a length of string. I am using black string so it will disappear in the dark but it really does not show much if it's another color.
lines.text_raw: Once you have the wrapping up around the head you need to tie it securely with a length of string. I am using black string so it will disappear in the dark but it really does not show much if it's another color.

lines.text: You can use the string to hang the head or secure it to a bush branch to help keep goblins from running off with your props.
lines.text_raw: You can use the string to hang the head or secure it to a bush branch to help keep goblins from running off with your props.

lines.text: The previous example wrapped the web around the head in a "gift basket" style (bottom to top). This example will roll the head in the webbing in a "cocoon" style. Great for half-shell heads and small parts.
lines.text_raw: The previous example wrapped the web around the head in a "gift basket" style (bottom to top). This example will roll the head in the webbing in a "cocoon" style. Great for half-shell heads and small parts.

lines.text: Lay the head on one side of your web. Fold web over in a criss-cross fashion, roll over once, then tuck in web to secure. Continue rolling up head until 3/4 of webbing has been used.
lines.text_raw: Lay the head on one side of your web. Fold web over in a criss-cross fashion, roll over once, then tuck in web to secure. Continue rolling up head until 3/4 of webbing has been used.

lines.text: Turn head  sideways so that remaining webbing is above the head.
lines.text_raw: Turn head  sideways so that remaining webbing is above the head.

lines.text: Secure with String!
lines.text_raw: Secure with String!

lines.text: Same idea as the full heads: secure the remaining webbing up on top of the head with string. Add a spider for decor.
lines.text_raw: Same idea as the full heads: secure the remaining webbing up on top of the head with string. Add a spider for decor.

lines.text: Wrap up other little bits to strew here and there in your decor. Make sure enough of the item sticks out so people know what it is; not just a wad of cotton-looking thing.
lines.text_raw: Wrap up other little bits to strew here and there in your decor. Make sure enough of the item sticks out so people know what it is; not just a wad of cotton-looking thing.

lines.text: After securing the wrapping with string take time to stick a plastic spider or two into the webbing. Please - no harm to the real spiders.
lines.text_raw: After securing the wrapping with string take time to stick a plastic spider or two into the webbing. Please - no harm to the real spiders.

lines.text: You don't have to put the heads in a hedge or bush; you can hang freely as-is. Add some plastic spiders and spread out the webbing a bit.
lines.text_raw: You don't have to put the heads in a hedge or bush; you can hang freely as-is. Add some plastic spiders and spread out the webbing a bit.

lines.text: That's All, Folks!
lines.text_raw: That's All, Folks!

lines.text: Quick and easy. Next I will place them into the hedge and then spread out more webbing over the entire hedge. Then add the big spiders, etc. I'll post a hedge pic soon.
lines.text_raw: Quick and easy. Next I will place them into the hedge and then spread out more webbing over the entire hedge. Then add the big spiders, etc. I'll post a hedge pic soon.

guide.summary: A simple prop for Halloween. Wrapping recycled / reused doll parts in webbing sold at Halloween. Use these in props & decor as 'captured victims' of spiders.
guide.title: WebHeads! Create Spiderweb-Trapped Doll Heads for Halloween

tools.text: Paper cutter, scissors, or utility knife
